item.description:
From the Coolidge Corner Theater site:

http://www.coolidge.org/content/frankenstein

"As part of its NT Live series, the Coolidge Corner Theatre presents high-definition broadcasts of FRANKENSTEIN, captured live from the stage of London’s National Theatre and transmitted to cinema screens around the world.  Oscar-winning filmmaker Danny Boyle (Slumdog Millionaire, 127 Hours), directs Nick Dear’s play, based on Mary Shelley’s Gothic novel about one driven scientist’s attempts to create life and the nameless creature that results from his experiment.  Childlike in his innocence but grotesque in form, the Creature is cast out into a hostile universe by his horror-struck maker, but is determined to track down the man who gave him life".

Price: $20.00 + service charge if bought online. Purchase tickets ahead of time at http://www.coolidge.org/content/frankenstein

Time: We get in line at 6:15 pm to be seated after picking up tickets at the ticket window. Doors and pre-show at 6:30 pm, production at 7:00 pm, continuing until 9:15 pm.

Where to Meet:

T.J. Maher will be at the Coolidge Corner Theater starting at 6:00 pm. Feel free to drop by and mingle with people! Starting at 6:15 pm the line for seating rain or shine starts outside and snakes along the brick wall. T.J. was planning on getting in line with the group then. The doors open at 6:30 pm with the pre-show starting soon before.

T.J. Maher is 5 foot 7 with short brown hair, blue eyes, a "Hello My Name is T.J." nametag, and a red MEETUP sign attached to his black messenger bag.

  

More About the Production:

http://www.coolidge.org/content/frankenstein

"One of the themes of Mary Shelley’s novel is how far the Creature can be seen as Frankenstein’s double. In the National Theatre’s unique production, the two lead actors, Jonny Lee Miller and Benedict Cumberatch, switch between the roles of Frankenstein and his 'hideous progeny' on a nightly basis.  The Coolidge’s March 17 broadcast will feature Miller as Dr. Frankenstein and Cumberbatch as the Creature, while the Monday April 4 broadcast will feature Cumberbatch as the scientist and Miller as his creation. 

"For more information and advance tickets, visit www.coolidge.org/ntlive. Tickets also available at the Coolidge box office, 290 Harvard Street, Brookline.  Advance purchase strongly recommended".

  

Slate Magazine: Frankenstein and His Monster: Live At The Movies.

http://www.slate.com/blogs/blogs/browbeat/archive/2011/02/24/frankenstein-and-his-monster-live-at-the-movies.aspx?wpisrc=obnetwork

"Last night in London, the National Theatre premiered its production of Frankenstein, to rave reviews. The Guardian sums up the day's critical consensus: 'Stunning, stunning, stunning, boring briefly, stunning again.' (The boring bits are apparently the fault of a leaden script, though the visuals and the performances are supposedly spectacular.)

"Directed by Slumdog Millionaire's Danny Boyle, the production stars Jonny Lee Miller and the too-good-to-be-true-ly named Benedict Cumberbatch (of the BBC's Sherlock). The actors alternate nights as Dr. Frankenstein and the Creature, highlighting the bond between the two characters.

"Those of us who won't be getting to London any time soon can take advantage of the National Theatre's NT Live program, which brings the company's performances to movie screens around the world—a far from perfect solution, but significantly cheaper than airfare".  

 

About the Coolidge Corner Theater:

http://www.coolidge.org/about/us

"Since 1933, audiences in the greater Boston area have relied on the Coolidge for the best of contemporary art house and independent film. The Coolidge also presents the prestigious annual Coolidge Award; high-definition broadcasts from London's National Theatre and Europe's Grand Operas; Big Screen Classics; Midnite cult films and sing-alongs; weekend kids' variety shows; and sneak previews and discussion of upcoming films as part of Talk Cinema. In 2008, the Coolidge was selected among distinguished arts organizations to be awarded significant funding from the Cultural Facilities Fund, a program administered by MassDevelopment and the Massachusetts Cultural Council. The Coolidge has won numerous awards and recognitions for creative and innovative programming".

Directions and Parking: Meters are free after 6:00 pm.

http://www.coolidge.org/about/directions-and-parking

"By train: take the Green Line (C branch to Cleveland Circle) trolley from downtown to Coolidge Corner via Beacon Street. The Coolidge Corner stop is at Harvard Street, 5-10 minutes from Kenmore Square".
item.why: Organizer: T.J. Maher. "Captured live from the stage of the UK's National Theatre, FRANKENSTEIN, directed by Oscar-winning filmmaker Danny Boyle (Slumdog Millionaire, 127 Hours). First 10 weeks already sold out in London!
item.name: National Theatre Live: FRANKENSTEIN
